Title: Owen Bradley
Medium: Bronze sculpture on a pedestal of concrete pavers.
Marks: Near the sculpture there is a half circle wall of brick with limestone cap and band. The limestone cap includes biographical information about Owen Bradley and the band lists songs and artists he produced:Owen Bradley (1915-1998) A gifted pianist, arranger, composer and record producer, Owen Bradley is recognized as one of the architects of the world-famous "Nashville Sound."  His humility, honesty and integrity made him a father figure for the entire Nashville music industry; he became a role model for all who have followed him.
Owner: Metro Gov. of Nashville & Davidson Co, Parks & Rec
Remarks: October 19, 1999 - sculpture was unveiled and dedicated at the Owen Bradley Park on Music Row. Following the dedication, the sculpture had a temporary home in the Presidential Lobby of the Opryland Hotel until construction of the Music Row Roundabout/streetscape and renovation of the Owen Bradley Park were completed and dedicated March 9, 2001.Bronze sculpture was fabricated at Metal Letters foundry in Lehi, Utah.As a part of this research in preparing the sculpture, the artist obtained clothing items from Owen Bradley's family including shoes, hat and lapel pins as well as videos and still photographs. Smith chose to portray Owen Bradley at approximately age 50 and located a model of similar size to sit for the initial clay model. The artist is preparing for the Bradley family a video of the entire process of producing the sculpture.

Title: Ghost Ballet for the East Bank Machineworks
Subject: Curved red trusses that appear to create a sphere sitting on top of a crane base once used to launch barges. There is a red turbine whirlwind on the ground below.
Remarks: This piece is a representation of the transformation of the East Bank from an industrial area to an area for recreation and play. The trusses and crane base show the past industrial use of the area, while the circular and changing motion represents the transformation of the area.

Remarks: At the roundabout by Music Row, this rack highlights the muscial tradition of Nashville

Title: Continuum
Medium: Acrylic on transparent tiles; some photographs
Subject: A series of 18 tiles printed with photographs or rust impressions of subjects meaningful to the local area
Remarks: The piece is above the information desk at the library and illuminates the rich history of Goodlettsville. The tiles represent pages and the information and history that can be found within the library. The artist created a companion book to more fully explain the piece and the history behind each tile.

Title: Seasons from a Bird's Eye View
Aileron
Subject: A sculpture of iron with 3 supporting legs with two wings on top. The wings spin 360 degrees

Title: Exploration and Discovery #1: The Spark of Discovery
Subject: Four children mesmerized by discovery of something. The base depicts a rabit in its nest.
Remarks: This is the first piece of "Exploration and Discovery" highlighting the role Nashville has played in art, science, and culture innovations. Amung other things, a saber tooth tiger skull is buried underneath the children as a reference to the skull found in the AmSouth building excavation and representing the things that came before us.

Title: Exploration and Discovery #2: The Scholar
Medium: Cast bronze, fabricated bronze, fabricated steel base
Subject: A scholar sitting in the middle of 8 telescopes surrounded by books.
Remarks: The second piece of "Exploration and Discovery" represents the active pursuit of knowledge. The rug beneath the scholar is worn from looking into the telescopes. The planets are in the astronomical position of December 25, 1779, the day James Robertson crossed the Cumberland River and onto the future site of Nashville. Six of the telescopes are aimed at Nashville landmarks and two at astronomical bodies.

Title: Exploration and Discovery #3: To the Moon
Medium: Bronze, cast glass with bronze rim, granite
Subject: A woman standing on a pile of books splits open the moon to change a lightbulb inside
Remarks: The third piece of "Exploration and Discovery" represents reaching the aim of knowledge as she only reaches the moon through standing on a tower of books and objects. The objects in the stack represent various aspects of local history, the musical tradition, space and astronomical exploration, and local flora and fauna.

Title: Citizen
Medium: Glass torsos with woven stainless steel base
Subject: Two conversing figures with outstretched arms. A mechanical system is set up for a person to rotate the torsos.
Remarks: The two figures represent the leaders of Nashville directing the development of the city, going back to founders James Robertson and John Donelson to Fisk and Tennessee A&I University students leading the Nashville Civil Rights reform to current leadership. The sculptures turn to represent every Nashvillian's participation in the city. At night, the sculptures are lit to serve as a beacon for a gathering place for all of Nashville.

Title: Tree of Learning
Subject: A tree with three trunks that create a space for a visitor to stand. The tree depicts images of figures, faces, and hands in the bark.
Remarks: The tree, with hands in the branches passing candles and new growth of leaves and buds, represents the passing and renewal of knowledge found at a university. This sculpture is the center of the "Garden of Great Ideas" collection.

Title: Ascension
Subject: A dome with two male figures, one on top of the dome and one under the dome.
Remarks: This work explores religion and self-awareness. The figure under the dome ("Penitence") represents those who are trapped by the institution of religion, while the figure on top of the dome ("Ecstacy") represents those who have achieved self-awareness through religion

Title: Con-volution
Subject: This piece represents the double-helix of a strand of DNA.
Remarks: This work represents the continuity of genetics and life as parents pass on DNA to children. Generations do not stay the same but constantly evolve and change as people are living beings contrary to inanimate objects.

Title: Shadow and Substance
Subject: Two figures, one on top looking down into his reflection.
Remarks: This work represents the conscious and unconscious minds. The conscious mind is looking down into his reflection of the unconcscious mind. The conscious mind throws one arm into the water with his unconscious mind as he attempts to find self-awareness. The other arm is bound behind him, representing how the conscious mind can be limiting. The unconscious mind is distorted to represent that there are limits to full self-knowledge.

Title: The Birth of Apollo
Medium: Bronze sculpture as centerpiece of fountain
Subject: Two figures topping a fountain, one with a lyre and one with a horn.

Title: The Flutist
Marks: Inscribed on base: "He will always be the music"
Subject: Statue commemorating Kenneth D Schermerhorn, Music Director and Conductor of the Nashville Symphony Orchestra from 1983-2005.

Title: The Recording Angel
Marks: Inscribed artist's name on robe; Inscribed "The recording angel inscribes the tones, that envelope the heart and heal the bones, that lighten life's toll, and soothe the soul" - Audrey Flack
Subject: Bronze angel holding a fountain pen and tablet

Title: Orpheus and Eurydice
Subject: Relief sculpture above main entrance of Schermerhorn Symphony Center

Title: Waveform: Pan American Blues
Subject: A series of 82 glass panels ranging in length from 7.5 feet to 14.5 feet. The panels are colored red, blue, and purple.
Remarks: This piece welcomes visitors to Nashville, showing them the hospitality and vitality of the city and the people. It alludes to Nashville's history and heritage as well as the growing cosmopolitan feel of the city. The piece was inspired by the song "Pan American Blues" by Country Music Hall of Fame member DeFord Bailey.

Title: Wind Reeds
Subject: Hinged aluminum panels that cover a wall of the Consolidated Rental Car facility. The panels move according to the wind
Remarks: This piece illuminates the invisible force of the wind and the mesmerizing effect that it can have when it is noticed. The surface of the aluminum changes with the color of the sky, sun, and clouds, and the wind.

Title: Timeless
Marks: Inscribed on base: J.Sorci
Subject: Two nearly interlinked hemicycles with cannonballs arranged within them.
Remarks: Sculpture created with cannonballs excavated in 1999 while building the Commerce Center. The cannonballs were believed to be made in the 1860's by a local foundry. This piece concentrates on a theme of the passage of time and looks machine-like, leaving the viewer to decide what the piece represents.

Title: Oh, Roy
Subject: Minnie Pearl and Roy Acuff seated on a bench inside Ryman Auditorium.
Remarks: Minnie Pearl, a comedian, and Roy Acuff, a musician, were two of the Grand Ole Opry's central tenants. The Grand Ole Opry took place at what is now Ryman Auditorium from 1925-1974.

Title: Tennessee Falls
Artist(s): Houge, Jon, Meek, Thom, & Swensson, Lin
Subject: A stone wall built with three types of stone with water falling down the wall into a pool at the bottom.

Title: Sundial
Medium: Steel, iron, bronze, brick, and stone (all recovered from demolition of building)
Artist(s): Jacobs, Dillard, Adamson, John, & Patton, James
Subject: A sundial in the shape of three metal rings forming a sphere
Remarks: This sundial was designed by a Vanderbilt professor and built by his students. The materials used were salvaged from the remnants of the Barnard Observatory which stood in this site from 1875-1952 when it was torn down to make room for Rand Hall.

Title: Map Turtle: Graptemys Geographica
Subject: A map of the world in the shape of a turtle
Remarks: The turtle shape is an interpretation of the map of the world. The work focuses on three themes of land-use throughout American history: techonological/industrial, agricultural, and hunter-gatherer.

Title: The Fault
Subject: A mother standing and bending away from her baby daughter who is on the floor grasping for her mother.
Remarks: This work explores the theme of a mother betraying her daughter. Culture promotes an image of a mother nurturing and supporting her child, but the instances of maternal violence are often forgotten. This piece shows the paradox between the mother being the ultimate nurturer for her child but also the ultimate destroyer.

Title: Solipsis
Subject: An abstract curved shape
Remarks: This work explores the philosophical idea of Solipsism (only one's own mind is certain to exist). The artist represents the creative struggle of overcoming one's own assumptions and weakness to express thoughts and feelings to other people's individual assumptions.

Title: The Ladder
Subject: A ladder in the shape of a double helix with 4 angels sitting on various rungs
Remarks: Inspired by the story of generations growing at Jacob's Ladder from the Bible, this ladder represents the idea that with more knowledge and discovery about genetics and our future generations. The diversity of the angels on the ladder represent the four races of humankind.

Title: Theme of Balance
Subject: An athlete balancing on one hand with arms and legs outstretched
Remarks: The athlete represents the ability to persevere and transpire what can seem impossible as the athlete's balance appears to defy gravity outstretched on top of a tall and small pillar.

Title: Dream Catchers
Subject: Two figures in movement
Remarks: These figures represent humanity's need to constantly explore his inner spirit and to discover something greater than himself. It pushes man to explore and outreach the limits of his mind.

Title: Being II Becoming
Subject: Four male torsos attached to a wall
Remarks: The four torsos express humanity's ever-changing and transforming being as we constant shift and reorganize.

Title: Armillary
Subject: Sphere comprised of three rings with an arrow running through the middle

Title: Balanced and Unbalanced Beam
Subject: Abstract red metal geometric shapes stacked on top of each other
Remarks: Benton strives to make his pieces "work" in three-dimensional space and has a lengthy process to ensure that they make a statement. Despite the bright red color, Benton sees the color as merely decorative as he focuses on the shape and space of the piece.

Title: Bishop's Grave
Subject: A decorative tomb marking the gravesite of 3 Methodist bishops
Remarks: This tomb marks the grave site of three Methodist bisphops. Bishop Holland N. McTyere was a founder of Vanderbilt University and the first president of the Board of Trust. Bishop William McKendree was the first American-born Methodist bishop as well as a soldier with George Washington's army. Lastly, Bishop Joshua Soule helped found the Methodist Episcopal Church. Additionally, Landon C. Garland, the first Chancellor of Vanderbilt, and his wife Amelia Townsend, are buried here.

Title: Black Cat
Medium: Polymer fortified cement with alkali resistant fiberglass mesh, polysterene foam core form, glass and ceramic tile
Subject: A croutching black cat made from mosaics
Remarks: Lynn Driver was awarded best middle level art teacher in 2002.

Title: Broken Victory
Subject: Long horizontal and vertical planes with spikes surrounding them
Remarks: This piece is a Vietnam War Memorial and a gift from Minna and Jacob Brussel

Title: Coming Home
Subject: A boy striding forward towards a door

Title: David
Subject: A figure of David sitting on a rock playing the lyre
Remarks: This sculpture was commissioned by Anne Potter Wilson for the Blair School of Music.

Title: Eldon B. Stevenson
Subject: A bust of Eldon B. Stevenson
Remarks: Eldon B. Stevenson was a member of the Vanderbilt Board of Trustees and the president of National Life and Accident Insurance Company. Stevenson funded the construction of Vanderbilt's Science Complex, which now bears his name.

Title: Flying Torso
Subject: A female torso balanced on proper right leg with other leg and arms outstretched
Remarks: This piece was donated from the Phi Chi Medical Fraternity from the Vanderbilt School of Medicine. The artist graduated from Vanderbilt in 1978 with a B.S. in English and Art History.

Title: Fountain
Subject: A small fountain surrounded by stones
Remarks: The fountain was dedicated in memory of Madeleine Joyce Goodman, Ph.D. 1945-1996.

Title: Fusion
Subject: Two pyramid shapes holding a sphere in the middle
Remarks: The artist explores the wonders and beauty of both the man-made and the natural world with this piece. He engages the viewer with the sense of line and space, as well as freedom from constraints and the seemingly impossible.

Title: Guardian Spirit
Subject: An abstract angel figure with wings outstretched and knees bent
Remarks: Best known as a musician, Alpert's piece has the same qualities of fluidity and softness as music.

Title: Imole Blue
Subject: 4,400 grape hyacinth bulbs planted in an arrangement outlining the streets of Manguito, Cuba
Remarks: In Yourba, "imole blue" means blue earth. A native of Manguito, Cuba, the artist attempts to outline the streets of her hometown. In this way, she creates a memory of place that resonates with the many Vanderbilt students and employees who have left hometowns and countries in pursuit of knowledge.

Title: Indeterminate Line
Subject: A long steel beam twisted into a circle resting on the ground.
Remarks: Venet has explored pieces around the theme of indeterminate lines since 1979 as twisting and bending the thick steel beams is a challenging physical and technical feat for artists. The work expresses the paradox between the ease of body movements and the challenge of manipulating steel beams.

Title: Korean Tomb Carving
Subject: A statue from the tomb site of an ancient Korean king.
Remarks: This statue was a gift to Peabody professor Willard Goslin from the South Korean Government. After the Korean War, Goslin led a group of Peabody faculty to South Korea to help rebuild the educational system in the country. At the same time, 32 South Korean educators came to Vanderbilt to earn doctoral degrees in Education from Peabody. Currently the Minister of Education in South Korea, as well as 75 percent of South Korean college and university deans earned a doctoral degree at Peabody College.

Title: Owl's Outlook
Subject: A series of animals (dog, deer, rabbit, duck, turtle) sitting on top of one another with an owl perched at the top of a tree branch.

Title: Piesterion: Diasematon 2
Subject: Four columns with bronze plates dissecting the columns
Remarks: This piece was inspired by the Antarctic ice cores. The work is titled from the Greek root "piester" meaning "press" referring to the forming of the ice caps, and the Greek prefix "dia" meaning "through" and "semata" meaning "signals" referring to inclusions that are found in ice cores. The inclusions are represented by the bronze plates in the columns.

Title: Seasonal Cycles
Subject: Mosaic of many different types of people at Vanderbilt doing different campus activities
Remarks: The artist is inspired by a theme of love and all of the positive and negative emotions that come along with love. Her work is not literal, but is a visual narrative to be interpreted by the viewer.

Title: Two Rings
Subject: Two bronze rings, one sitting on top of the other.

Title: Pietrasanta (Holy Stone)
Subject: Abstract collection of geometric shapes

Title: Pure Heart
Medium: Tennessee Cedar marble with black marble base
Subject: A carved marble heart with indentation on the left side
Remarks: Placed in a garden of the Vanderbilt Hospital, these piece is a centerpoint of reflection for patients, families, doctors, and students. The heart reflects the strength, simplicity, and beauty of the physical and emotional human heart.

Title: Rock Specimens
Subject: Iron ore rocks from near Centerville and Rockville, TN
Remarks: These two large rocks were first displayed at the TN Cetennial Exhibition in 1897. They were moved to their current location on Vanderbilt's campus when the Geology Department occupied Garland Hall from 1928-1977.

Title: Spitting Images
Subject: Fountain with three concrete head spouts

Title: Star Chamber
Subject: A life-size chamber that functions as a camera-obscura. The horizon and sky is projected as an image on the wall once the viewer is inside the chamber. The star chamber also functions as a sundial during the day.
Remarks: The whole structure is simply held together by notched logs and stones. The outer rock arms represent the spiral of the galaxy. Once inside, the sky and horizon is projected through the top opening all around the walls of the chamber. A second hole at the top of the chamber only allows in a point of light at exactly noon, thus acting as a sundial. The standing rocks surrounding the outside of the chamber mark the sunrise and sunset of the solstice and equinox days.

Title: The Annointed
Subject: A woman with clapsed hands stretching up towards the sky.
Remarks: Jackson strives to portray the movement, expression, and story behind all of his figures. He has a common theme of showing the power of women as opposed to the media's portrayal of women throughout his work.

Title: The Bent
Subject: Symbol of the Tau Beta Pi Engineering Honor Society

Title: The Pursuit of Knowledge
Subject: Two figures with arms outstretched grasping for a golden cloud-like structure.
Remarks: This sculpture represents the pursuit of knowledge and information.

Title: Undulation
Subject: A wavy panel of copper with stainless steel rods running through it.

Title: Tumbleweed
Subject: Abstract red steel beams converging in the center

Title: Circle of Peace
Subject: A circle of 5 children holding hands and running around
Remarks: The circle of children represents the diversity of the world, and how, when there is interaction and relationships between people of different races, there can be no discrimation and segregation. The cooperation, respect, and joy of the children encompasses all of humanity. There is a space left in the circle for a child to interact with the piece, allowing a child to close the gap and complete the circle

Title: Circus Horse and Rider
Subject: A bronze sculpture of a horse with a woman balancing on one foot on its back. The woman is holding rings in both hands and in one foot.
Remarks: Bill Doak was a Vanderbilt pre-med undergraduate who started sculpting during his time at Vanderbilt. He subsequently completed his residency at Vanderbilt and since then, has donated many sculptural pieces to the hospital in order to give something beautiful to the children at the hospital. This sculpture was commissioned by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ritzen to celebrate Vanderbilt Children's Hospital opening as "a hospital within a hospital".

Title: Cutouts
Subject: A little girl sitting on a bench cutting out paper dolls.
Remarks: This piece was donated by Cayce Joyce who stumbled across the piece and bought it for the Children's Hospital as paper doll cutouts are the symbol of the Children's Hospital. The sculpture represents a childhood free of responsibility and worry, with only time to create and enjoy.

Title: Mother with Children
Subject: A mother walking and holding hands with her two young children.
Remarks: Created by local pediatrician and sculptor Bill Doak to give something enjoyable and beautiful to the children at the hospital.

Title: Running Girl
Subject: Small girl running forward

Title: Splish Splash
Subject: A globe with two children turning backflips. The children's feet are touching at the top, forming a heart in the negative space between their bodies and legs.
Remarks: The sculpture was commissioned by Phil and Mary Farris Martin to memorialize their son, Alexander, who died of cardiac arrest at the age of 10. As the piece was being finished, Mary Farris died unexpectedly. The piece was donated to the newly-opening children's hospital in memory of both of them and has since become the signature piece of the hospital.

Title: Thread (Connector Bridge)
Subject: Design on the fence of the bridge with a thread running throughout various quilt squares which have been created by the community.
Remarks: The artwork concept for the 28th Avenue Connector Bridge centers on themes of connectivity. The bridge is intended to connect two formerly separated neighborhoods and cultural areas. Dahlquist explores the new connectivity through themes of sewing, thread, and tying. Dahlquist ties all of this together with the metaphor of quilting to building community. Dahlquist will work with the community to develop individual quilt square patters, each of which will act as a QR code that links back to video and content of the community members' stories and background.

Title: Needle and Thread (Transit Shelter)
Subject: A transit shelter with a thread woven through the mesh wall with a needle running vertically by the shelter.
Remarks: This transit shelter compliments the theme of quilting and connectivity that runs through the connector bridge.

Title: Magnolia Shelters at Charlotte Avenue and 28th/31st Avenue
Subject: Transit shelters with magnolia branches and flowers on the screen and columns and a bent roof supporting the structure.
Remarks: These transit shelters continue the theme of connectivity by drawing inspiration from both Hadley Park and Centennial Park. The roof of the structure is mirrored after the roof of the amphitheater in Hadley Park, while the columns are modeled after those on the Parthenon replica. The magnolia shade screens and cast concrete bench celebrate the beauty of the magnolia trees in our community.

Title: KVB Roundabout
Subject: Artist currently being selected

Title: Liquid 615
Medium: Blue glass, LED lighting, galvanized metal
Subject: Waterdrops dropping off of a metal pole running alongside the outside community center wall.
Remarks: Allison writes, The drops represent the flood waters, but also the tears of the individuals in the Antioch community. When I participated in the community meeting, I was so struck by the stories of the communitys strength and perseverance after the flood in Antioch. These individual drops are all held together by a strong galvanized metal to represent this bond that held the community together in the aftermath of such tragedy.

Title: Untitled (Pier)
Subject: Windsocks on fifteen foot polls, each inscribed with adjectives that describe the river and the people.
Remarks: Cot describes, The artwork is intended to provide a place for visitors to slow down and reflect on the beauty and physical presence of the Cumberland River rather than be reminded specifically ofthe devastating floods of 2010.The designs most prominent feature isa series of four to five windsocks mounted atop fifteen-foot high aluminum masts. Each windsock iscustom appliqud with two adjectives (one on each side) that describe the majestic nature of the river and the tenacity of the residents The goal is tochoose adjectives that universally illustrate the river and the people ofthis neighborhood.

Title: Tool Fire
Medium: Welded metal hand tools, metal pipe, paint
Subject: Metal handtools welded together and painted black in the shape of flames over a firepit.
Remarks: Artist Christopher Fennell writes, Referencing the tremendous clean up efforts by the community and volunteers, the sculpture is a construction of hand tools over the existing fire pit next to the suspension bridge. The shape of each panel will be built from tools welded together and painted black. Fennell intends the artwork to look like waves within the fire

Title: Emergence
Subject: A large face of an African American woman emerging from the ground
Remarks: Jackson writes, "I learned at the community meeting, that unlike other areas of Nashville, the flood is very much still in the Bordeaux communityMany homes still remain abandoned, and many people are still struggling to find resolution. I also discovered a very strong sense of pride in the community of Bordeauxa determination that they will emerge from the water intact, made whole, and stronger than ever. My concept is to construct a large face of an African-American woman emerging from the earth. This face would serve as a symbol of every individual story of danger, loss, strength and determination to push through the setbacks caused by both nature and of humans, and emerge proud and strong from the swirling waters."

Title: Anchor in the Storm
Medium: Yellow pine logs, limestone boulder, anchor chain
Subject: A wooden platform constructed out of pine logs anchored by a chain to a limestone boulder
Remarks: Collaborative artists Lee & Betty Benson write, Our piece is conceived on the ties between the West Park neighborhood and the Rogers Group, Inc. REOStone Limestone Quarry; we see the two inextricably linked by the millennial flood that occurred in May, 2010.

Title: Bellevue Bench Mark
Subject: A bench with the Harpeth River traced on the top surface. An incription around the rim of the seat comments on the flood
Remarks: Artist Craig Nutt writes about his experience participating in the Bellevue community meeting, "Flood experiences ranged from helping neighbors to the loss of family members. The participants portrayed a community that is neighborly, resolute, resilient and proud of the way they pulled together during and after the floodnot victims, but survivors." Nutt describes, "The bench is derived from maps of the May 2010 flood in Bellevue. The blue line traces the riverbed of the Harpeth River as it winds through Bellevue. The path of the riverbed extends below the top surface (flood waters) to provide support to the bench."

Title: Reflection
Subject: A mockingbird with a mirror-like surface appearing to be mercurious and liquid. The bird is looking at a swirling wall with a hole in the center.
Remarks: The mockingbird is Tennessee's state bird as well as an intelligent and playful bird. Inspiration comes from the site's history as an amusement park and is expressed in the bird's mirror-like surface which is constantly changing what it reflects. The wall and the hole suggest curiosity and passage as well as carrying the theme of play and amusement.

Title: Star
Subject: This design uses the frames of six recycled bikes to create a geometric bike rack.
Remarks: Allen's goal in creating this bike rack was to create a visually and artistically appealing piece while still being functional. The rack also encourages environmentally healthy lifestyles and practices, just as Allen has salvaged bikes from junk yards to repurpose and reuse.

Title: Pedal Petroleum
Subject: Bright yellow, green, red, and black facsimile of antique gas pump.
Remarks: This design references Nashville's efforts and successes in becoming a green community. The antique gas pump serving as a bike rack reinforces Nashville's new image as well as the message of a cleaner and healthier community relying more on bikes and exercise and less on cars and gas.

Title: Handlebar Moustache
Subject: A handlebar moustache serving as a bike rack.
Remarks: Inspired by Nashville's love and history of interesting facial hair, Handlebar Moustache plays on the city's sense of humor. Furthermore, the "handlebar moustache" gets its name from the bicycle part of the same name during the art nouveau period.

Title: City Irises
Subject: Three painted metal irises
Remarks: Inspired by the state flower of Tennessee and designed to add color and whimsy to a Nashville street corner

Title: On Air
Subject: An abstracted radio tower with a ball crowning the top inscribed with "On Air". From the top, there are radio waves and lightning bolts.
Remarks: Inspired by the history of live radio and music in Nashville.

Title: Good Eats
Medium: Fiberglass with faux wood finish, stainless steel pipes, steel
Subject: A wire whisk sitting on a round steel plate of "liquid" that the whisk is stirring.
Remarks: One of the criteria that makes a great city is its food. Nashville has a great restaurant and local food scene, and that is represented in this bike rack through one of the basic kitchen tools: the whisk.

Title: Airwaves
Subject: Operational bike pumps on either end of the wave with sound waves flowing out of them, as if created by the pumps.

Title: Sound Board Sliders
Subject: A representation of the volumn control sliders found on a sound board in all music studios.

Title: Almost There
Subject: A time-lapse sequence depicting a pair of running legs. It is an anthropomorphization of the traditional u-shape bike rack.
Remarks: This rack illustrates Nashville's emphasis on healtha and exercising along with its playful and creative side.

Title: Lyrical Rider
Subject: A fluid bicycalist and bike with a musical staff encorporated into the wheel
Remarks: This rack is easily visible to cyclists as a bike rack and merges the musical creativity and legacy of Nashville with the healthy and environmentally-friendly side of Nashville.

Title: No title given: (Cumberland Museum and Science Center Mural, (sculpture)
Marks: signed
Subject: A ceramic mural depicting the main types of trees and geological features of Nashville-Davidson County, TN.  The mural shows a cross section of the earth with the geological layers beneath the surface and the rolling hills and river valleys above the surface.  On the surface are various species of trees found in the area.  The mural is located on an exterior wall of a building.  It juts out and them back in towards the wall of the science center in a zigzag shape.  The colors of the mural are tan and brown.Landscape -- Tennessee -- Nashville.Landscape -- River -- Harpeth RiverLandscape -- River -- Stones RiverLandscape -- River -- Cumberland RiverWaterscape -- Lake -- J.Percy Priest ReservoirAnimal -- Deer
Condition: Surveyed in 1992 July.  Well maintained.
Remarks: IAS files contain a flyer on the mural which describes the ecological-geological profile of Nashville-Davidson County. Title: Tennessee Fox Trot Carousel
Subject: The figures on the merry-go-round depict 36 important figures from Tennessee history, including Andrew Jackson, the Everly Brothers, and Goo-Goo Boy among others.
Condition: No longer at Riverfront Park; now disassembled at the TN State Museum
